results.headline: Intent on Defying an All-Seeing Eye
results.summary_short: “Citizenfour,” about Edward J. Snowden’s quest to expose sweeping government surveillance of citizens, has the effect of a spooky and deeply unsettling thriller.

results.headline: Mom Won’t Find Us; She Disappeared or Something
results.summary_short: “White Bird in a Blizzard,” a coming-of-age story, stars Shailene Woodley.

results.headline: How Do You Say ‘Rough Customers’ in Russian?
results.summary_short: Gérard Depardieu stars in a gangster film set in his adopted country, Russia.

results.headline: A Snowstorm Arrives, and the Flakes Are Here
results.summary_short: “Tiger Lily Road,” a comedy directed by Michael Medeiros, finds a man on the run who meets two women with plans of their own.

results.headline: Dating at a Distance
results.summary_short: Zachary Wigon examines long-distance Internet relationships in “The Heart Machine,” with John Gallagher Jr. and Kate Lyn Sheil.

results.headline: In the Grip of New York’s Chinese Gangs
results.summary_short: “Revenge of the Green Dragons,” by Andrew Lau and Andrew Loo, shows the violent side of immigrant life in 1980s New York.

results.headline: If the Planchette Moves You
results.summary_short: Summoning evil spirits is a deadly game in “Ouija,” directed by Stiles White.

results.headline: A Daughter’s View of Dad, the Jazz Pianist and Addict
results.summary_short: “Low Down” is based on Amy-Jo Albany’s memoir about growing up as the daughter of the bebop pianist Joe Albany.

results.headline: Some People Persist in Taking an Endless Timeout From Adult Life
results.summary_short: Keira Knightley tries to dodge adult life in “Laggies,” Lynn Shelton’s hybrid of coming-of-age story and romantic comedy.

results.headline: Anything but Gentle on His Mind
results.summary_short: “Glen Campbell ... I’ll Be Me,” a documentary by James Keach, captures the final concert tour of a country music legend in the grip of Alzheimer’s disease.

results.headline: Something Out There, Behind the Trees
results.summary_short: Five young friends who go camping in the remote Texas woods encounter a terrifying predator in Eduardo Sanchez’s “Exists.”

results.headline: Before You Make a Move, Picture All Those Made in the Past
results.summary_short: The documentary “Algorithms” follows blind chess players in India and their teacher.

results.headline: Touchdowns in the Face of Adversity
results.summary_short: Dylan Baker directs “23 Blast,” based on the true story of a high school football player who lost his sight.

results.headline: Insatiably, She Leaps Into the Fray
results.summary_short: “1,000 Times Good Night” centers on a war photographer, played by Juliette Binoche, whose risk-taking unnerves her family.

results.headline: Gallantry and Glamour in a War Zone
results.summary_short: “E-Team,” a documentary, follows the high-risk work of four globe-trotting investigators for the organization Human Rights Watch.

results.headline: He Suffers for Art, and Forces Everyone Around Him to Do So
results.summary_short: In the dyspeptic comedy “Listen Up Philip,” Jason Schwartzman plays a shabby, self-loathing novelist whose agonies affect everyone around him.

results.headline: Advanced Course in Diversity
results.summary_short: Justin Simien’s “Dear White People” explores the hypocrisy, awkward good will and unwitting racism that hamper relations between white and black students at a fictional Ivy League school.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dear White People

results.headline: Former Screen Star, Molting on Broadway
results.summary_short: Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s comedy “Birdman” stars Michael Keaton as a onetime movie superhero betting his career on a strange Broadway play.

results.headline: A Mission for Justice in the Face of Genocide
results.summary_short: “Watchers of the Sky” examines genocide and the work of the human-rights pioneer Raphael Lemkin and others to combat it.
